titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to his Papers at the Indiana University Archives
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Walaa Al Salmi.

note.p: © 2010 Trustees of Indiana University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-04 05:14:31 -0500.

did.abstract: Robert Gray Gunderson was an Indiana University professor of speech communication and history, and a former director of IU's American Studies Program. He began working at IU in 1958 and remained until his retirement in 1985. The collection consists of Gunderson's teaching materials, committee files, Speech Department records, correspondence, publications and newsletters, and student papers.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Student papers and recommendations subseries, located within the Teaching files series, is closed to researchers at this time. Other select files restricted; these are indicated in the finding aid. Advance notice required for access.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Robert Gray Gunderson was born in Madison, Wisconsin in 1915. He received his B.S. from the University of Wisconsin in 1937, and in 1941 he received his M.A. from Oberlin College. He completed his graduate studies at the University of Wisconsin, receiving his Ph.D. in 1949.

Before joining the Indiana University faculty, Gunderson spent a lengthy period of time as a member of the Oberlin College faculty, beginning at the rank of instructor in 1938 and becoming Professor in 1955. In 1952, he was named chairman for the Department of Speech, a position he held until 1958, when he left Oberlin for Indiana University. At IU, he served as a professor in speech and theater and as the director of graduate studies in the Department of Speech and Theater. He offered seminars in American public communication from the colonial period through the New Deal, and directed nearly 50 doctoral students in American Studies. In 1985 he was awarded the Distinguished Teaching Award by the IU Student Association.

From 1961 to 1965 Gunderson chaired the American Studies Committee in the IU Graduate School, which ultimately led to the creation of the graduate program in American Studies. He directed the program from 1968-1978. He retired in 1985.

In addition to numerous journal articles, he was the author of two books: The Log Cabin Campaign, a study of the 1840 presidential election, and The Old Gentleman's Convention: The Washington Peace Conference of 1861. Furthermore, he served in various editorial capacities for the Indiana Magazine of History, the Quarterly Journal of Speech, and the Journal of American History. He also served on the board or as an officer for several organizations such as the Southern Historical Association, the Organization of American Historians, and the Speech Communication Association. He died at the age of 81 on November 24, 1996.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four Series: Teaching files, Indiana University committee and departmental files, Correspondence, and Subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Gunderson's material has been organized into four series: Teaching files (1946-1985), Indiana University committee and departmental files (1953-1987), Correspondence (1953-1980), and Subject files (1949-1982).

The first series, Teaching files (1946-1985), is further organized into three sub-series: Course materials (1953-1985), Student papers and recommendations (1949-1978) and Subject files (1946-1983). Course materials are arranged by course number and include syllabi, exam questions, lecture notes and related clippings. The majority of the materials under the second sub-series, Student papers and recommendations is restricted from public use at this time. Arranged alphabetically, the subject files contain articles and bibliographies on topics relating to American studies and speech communication including bibliographies, and files on great orators such as Alexander Hamilton and Woodrow Wilson.

The second series, Indiana University committee and departmental files (1953-1987) is organized into two sub-series: General (1959-1978) and American Studies and Speech Department (1959-1987). The General sub-series consists of files on university-wide committees that Gunderson participated in such as the Committee on Ethics and the University Bicentennial Committee. The second sub-series contains committee and departmental files specific to the American Studies program as well as the Department of Speech and Theater.
Correspondence (1953-1980), the third series, contains general chronological correspondence files, correspondence with alumni, and other departmental related correspondence.

The final series, Subject files (1949-1982), consists of files relating to Gunderson's professional activities outside of Indiana University. Files cover his involvement with the American Studies Association (ASA), Committee on the History of American Public Address (CHAPA), Federal Communication Commission (FCC), National Honorary Forensic Society, and the Speech Association of America (SAA). This series also contains two of Gunderson's published articles.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Some restricted materials were removed from the collection and destroyed, such as student grades. Other restricted material has been listed where it falls intellectually in the collection organization but has been physically placed at the end of the collection. Researchers will need permission from the archivist to view those records.
A photograph has been taken out from the correspondence series in the dissertations in progress folder. Consult Archives Photographs Curator for details.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor(s) of this collection have not transferred their copyrights for the materials to the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Robert Gray Gunderson papers, Collection C190, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Transferred to the Archives by Amy Cornell from the Dept. of Communication and Culture, Oct. 2003.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Duplicates of reading lists have been pulled out and publications that were neither written nor edited by Gunderson were also pulled out.
